Award.AwardTitle: AGS-PRF: Synthesizing Laboratory and Field Measurements of Biogenic Volatile Organic Compounds
Award.AbstractNarration:
This objective of this research is to investigate the major chemical and physical loss pathways for isoprene (C5H8) and its oxidation products in the atmosphere and assess their role in the formation of secondary organic aerosol (SOA). An AGS Postdoctoral Research Fellow will conduct laboratory studies in Caltech's newly built smog chambers to explore potential mechanisms for SOA formation under various conditions. The three primary mechanisms that will be investigated are: (1) the gas-phase OH-oxidation of isoprene-derived epoxydiols (IEPOX), that are formed in pristine environments, in the presence of varying amounts of NOx, (2) the reactive uptake and aqueous photochemistry of isoprene-derived organic compounds (hydroperoxide (ISOPOOH), IEPOX, glycolaldehyde, etc.) in aerosol liquid water, and (3) the formation of hydroperoxides from the water vapor reaction with stabilized Criegee intermediates from the ozonolysis of isoprene.

Multifunctional organic compounds that are important precursors to SOA were measured during an NSF sponsored field campaign in the summer of 2013, the Southern Oxidant and Aerosol Study (SOAS), using a state-of-the-art chemical ionization mass spectrometer (CIMS). Results from the laboratory studies will be used to assess possible mechanisms for SOA formation that might explain the observational data collected during the SOAS field campaign.

Isoprene is emitted by forests and plants and is among the most highly emitted organic compounds in the atmosphere. The products of isoprene oxidation form ozone and secondary organic aerosols, which are harmful to human health and perturb the Earth's climate. This research will produce information that is critical to modeling the influence of isoprene oxidation products on climate change.

This research is supported under the AGS Postdoctoral Research Fellowship program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Chemical compounds emitted to the atmosphere (whether by humans or plants) will get oxidized, eventually forming inert gases such as CO2 or heavy molecules that form suspended particles (secondary organic aerosols, or “SOA”). Atmospheric scientists can do a good job of predicting the atmospheric composition if they know the following:(1) the dynamic mixing and exchange of gases on a local/global scale, (2) the emission rates for important hydrocarbons from trees and urban areas, and (3) the hundreds of key chemical reactions that occur in the troposphere. It has recently come to light that the computational models we use to simulate the atmosphere does an especially poor job around regions where natural emissions (biogenic hydrocarbons) mix with urban pollutants, like the Southeast USA. The simplified story is that there are more particles (a haze that can be seen from space) and less ozone than predicted. The model/measurement disagreement likely points to major holes in our understanding of biogenic oxidation reactions and/or biosphere-atmosphere exchange dynamics. Furthermore, we have a limited understanding of what happens to oxidized compounds from isoprene and other hydrocarbons once they are formed.

        This proposal tackles open questions in biogenic oxidation chemistry using a combination of laboratory experiments, ambient observations, and atmospheric modeling. The principal investigator of the proposal, Dr. Tran B. Nguyen, conducted experiments during two large collaborative campaigns – the Southern Oxidant and Aerosol Study (SOAS), set in an Alabama forest, and the Focused Isoprene eXperiment at California Institute of Technology (FIXCIT), performed in the environmental chambers at Caltech. Dr. Nguyen further investigated the SOA formation for the oxidation products of isoprene in the laboratory. The PI disseminated the results from this proposal in 5 first-author peer-reviewed publications, alongside several contributed publications and conference presentations. Key findings are summarized briefly below:

  • During the SOAS campaign, Dr. Nguyen and coworkers placed their mass spectrometer on top of a 65-ft metal walk-up tower to measure oxygenated gases above the forest canopy. The rate that these gases get deposited onto the canopy (where they may be respired or coat plant surfaces), were still unknown at the time. Models used best-guess estimations based on unfamiliar molecules. The PI directly measured deposition for 16 oxidized compounds and demonstrated that they can be fast (and dominant) for some species. Thus, past discrepancies in model predictions may be mostly due to incorrect deposition rates. Further, Dr. Nguyen used the data to develop a new framework to calculate deposition rates for complex molecules that have not yet been measured. 1
  • During the FIXCIT campaign, Dr. Nguyen and coworkers designed and performed a month’s worth of environmental chamber experiments to study the interesting observations at SOAS in a controlled setting.2 A few noteworthy findings are: the formation of previously-unmeasured species that may produce SOA,3 a chemical formation pathway for nitrogen-containing peroxides observed in the atmosphere,4 and the unexpected degradation of major atmospheric compounds in common instrumentation (leading to altered measurements).5
  • The PI investigated the surface-active chemistry of IEPOX, a second-generation compound from isoprene (only when the oxidation happens in a clean atmosphere) that is known to produce SOA.6 This work is the first to focus on non-acidic pathways in IEPOX’s surface reaction and demonstrated the importance of particle water and dissolved ions for SOA formation from IEPOX.
